Replies.Reply: Fine! Fine! She ought to like this.
Open the door.
Oh, no.
Mullison! Come on!
Well, orders are orders! Somebody's gotta take it in.
Fredericks!
These pigs! They're afraid to take her food in.
Who's gonna take it in to her? You?
Come on! Make up your mind!
Left twenty minutes ago.
Sorry, Miss. It's gone.

Ellie's face clouds. The crowds surge about her. She looks around thoughtfully. Suddenly her eyes open in surprise at something she sees, and the view then moves over to Peter, who sits on his suitcase, looking toward Ellie.
Replies.Didascalie: (and he turns his back on her)

Replies.Reply: Eight o'clock tonight.
Sorry, Miss.
Not me, sir. She threw a ketchup bottle at me this morning.
Before I bring her another meal, I'll be put off the ship first.
No, Monsieur. When I leave the Ritz you do not say I have to wait on crazy womans.
What's up? What's up?
That's ridiculous! Afraid of a mere girl!
Why didn't you do it yourself?
I never heard of such a thing! Afraid of a mere girl.
I'll take it in myself.
Can't get a thing done unless you do it yourself.
Open the door.
Afraid of a mere girl! Ridiculous.
She refused another meal, sir.
On a hunger strike, huh?
When'd she eat last?
Been sending her meals in regularly?
Why didn't you jam it down her throat?
Absurd!
All this fuss over a snip of a girl.
I'm going down to see her myself.
What's this! What's happened here?
Get another tray ready. Bring it here at once.
Open the door.
What's this about not eating?
Know what my next move is? No more cigarettes.
I might.
Come on, Ellie. Stop being silly. You know I'm going to have my way.
Not so far as I'm concerned, you're not.
Yes?
Wait a minute! Don't get excited! This isn't for you.
Put it right here.
No. Everything seems quite satisfactory. I may want some more of that delicious gravy. I'll ring.
Heavenly!
If Gandhi had a chef like Paul, it would change the whole political situation in India.
Please. I can't fight on an empty stomach. Remember what Napoleon said.
South America.
We leave Miami in an hour. Soon's we get some supplies aboard.
In that event, we won't need so many supplies.
I'll get it annulled.
were dragged in, staggering drunk. You probably were.
Nothing much. I just think he's a fake, that's all.
That was enough. Do you mind handing me the ketchup?
Gigolo? Why, you took the word right out of my mouth. Thanks.
You're going to finance him, I suppose.
He's no good, Ellie, and you know it. You married him only because I told you not to.
You'll be set free when the marriage is annulled.
A time will come when you'll thank me for this.
Please don't shout.
Ah! Coconut layer cake. Nice and gooey, too. Just the way I like it.
Ellie!

Next on the DECK, at the open cabin door, Andrews is seen, staring off at something and an amazed, frightened look comes into his eyes. Then, as viewed from his position at the cabin door, Ellie appears standing on the rail; and with a professional dive, she leaps into the water.
It's my daughter! Go after her.
you.
Terrible! Nothing terrible about her. She's great! Marvelous youngster! Got a mind of her own. Knows just what she wants.
She's not going to get it though. She won't get very far. Has no money.
Holy Smoke! I forgot all about that.
Any others?
What do they say?
Amateurs!
I thought I made it clear I was in a hurry to get to New York?
What are we crawling for!
Well, step on it! Step on it!
Of course she's all right. What do you think can happen!
Then shut up about it!
All you've shown me is a stack of feeble reports from those comical detectives of yours. I want action, Lovington!
Replies.Didascalie: (in a close view at the desk)

Replies.Reply: What I'm asking isn't impossible. My daughter is somewhere between here and Miami. I want her found!
It's not enough!
Are you certain she's not with King Westley?
I'm worried, Lovington. After all, something might have happened to her.
Replies.Didascalie: (who has been pressing several buttons on his desk)

Replies.Reply: coast hook-up! Offer a reward of ten thousand dollars for any information leading to her whereabouts.
Send the story out to the newspapers.
I haven't changed my mind, Westley, I want you to understand that! I don't like you! I never have! I never will! That's clear enough, isn't it?
You've got a good thing and you're hanging on to it, huh?

All right, You win. I'll just have to get used to you. I admit I'm licked. But only because I'm worried. I've had detectives all over the country searching for her. I've seen thousands of photographs. Fortune tellers, nuts, every crank in the country has written me.
Replies.Didascalie: (Andrews smiles in a very superior manner)

Replies.Reply: Haven't slept one night this week. If I don't find her, I'll go crazy.
Yes. I know. Well, you can help now. I issued a statement yesterday that I've withdrawn my objections. Begging her to come home. I haven't heard from her. Apparently she doesn't trust me.
All right. That's why I sent for you.
As Andrews opens the door, a number of reporters enter.
King Westley.
He has a statement to make.
Can't you get them to go any faster?
This dissolves to a deserted ROAD, Peter at the wheel of his car. His high spirits find expression in his efforts to sing.
Replies.Didascalie: (at this the Inspector leans over to talk to chauffeur)

Replies.Reply: Later, boys, later. See her at home.
Well, here we are; it's all set. You're finally going to be married properly.
With all the fanfare and everything.
Naturally.
You're going to become a partner in a big institution. It's one of the largest in the world.
Someday perhaps, you might even take charge.
The thought of it makes me shudder.
You might be surprised.
I hope so. However, that'll take care of itself.
There's another responsibility you're taking on. One that I'm really concerned about.
My daughter.
I've never been able to do a thing with her. She's been too much for me. I'm glad you think it's easy.
Sock her!
Maybe.
Do we understand each other?
Fine. I'll see you at the reception.
You thought that up all by yourself, huh?
Personally, I think it's stupid!
But go ahead. Have a good time. As long as Ellie doesn't object.
We've done that already.
Autogyro! I hope he breaks his leg.
How is she?
What's the matter? Anything wrong?
Yes. I know. Still in the dumps, huh?
I knocked several times.
Replies.Didascalie: (a close view as he goes over to her)

Replies.Reply: Well, everything's set. Creating quite a furor, too. Great stunt King's going to pull.
Landing on the lawn in an autogyro.
Yes. Personally, I think it's silly, too.
What's the matter, Ellie? What's wrong?
Isn't all this what you wanted?
You haven't changed your mind about King, have you?
You know, the old pump isn't what it used to be.
child?
I thought so. I knew there was something on your mind.
What is it, darling?
You haven't fallen in love with somebody else, have you?
Have you?
Ellie now rises and walks miserably away from him, dabbing her eyes. Andrews, watching her, realizes he has hit upon the truth. He walks over to her.
Replies.Didascalie: (Ellie turns her head away, a little ashamed of her tears)

Replies.Reply: I haven't seen you cry since you were a baby. This must be serious.
Where'd you meet him?
Now, don't tell me you fell in love with a bus driver!
Who is he?
Ridiculous!
Well!
Fine man to fall in love with.
Well, what are we going to do about it? Where is he?
I'd like to have a talk with him.
Well, under the circumstances, don't you think we ought to call this thing off?
You've changed, Ellie.
Is that his name?
Peter Warne!
Why, no . . . Don't be silly.
I'm sorry you read it.
I suppose so.
I'll be going.
Ellie swallows her drink and starts pouring herself another, as King enters.
I leave for Washington tonight. May be gone several weeks. Thought perhaps you'd like to get this thing settled.
Show him in.
Mr. Warne?
Come in. Sit down.
I was surprised to get your note. My daughter hadn't told me anything about you. About your helping her.
Please understand me. When I say she didn't tell me anything about it, I mean not until a little while ago. She thinks you're entitled to anything you can get.
dollars and sixty cents?
Let me get this straight. You want this thirty-nine sixty in addition to the ten thousand dollars?
The reward.
You're a peculiar chap.
You were taken for a buggy ride?
Certainly.
While Andrews writes, Peter wanders around the room in an attitude of bitter contempt. Andrews rises and goes to him.
Replies.Didascalie: (he opens a checkbook and writes it out)

Replies.Reply: Here you are.
Do you mind if I ask you something frankly?
Do you love my daughter?
Replies.Didascalie: (Peter just looks at him without responding)

Replies.Reply: That's an evasion.
Do you love her?
I asked you a question. Do you love her?
I just had a long talk with him.
You're a sucker to go through with this.
Replies.Didascalie: (whispering out of the side of his mouth)

Replies.Reply: That guy Warne is O.K. He didn't want the reward.
perceptible.
He loves you, Ellie. Told me so.
You don't want to be married to a mug like Westley.
I can buy him off for a pot of gold, and you can make an old man happy, and you wouldn't do so bad for yourself. If you change your mind, your car's waiting at the back gate.
I haven't the slightest idea.
talk to anybody. Don't want to see anybody.
Ooooooh.

Hello my would-be ex-son-in-law. I've sent you a check for a hundred thousand. Yes. That's the smartest thing you ever did, Westley, not to contest that annulment. That's satisfactory, isn't it? Yeah. Well, it ought to be. Oh I'm not complaining. It was dirt cheap.
Don't fall out of any windows.
"What's holding up the annulment, you slow poke? The Walls of Jericho are toppling."
Send him a telegram right away. Just say: "Let 'em topple."
today.
Yessir. She refuses them all.
It's not quite that simple.
This is dangerous business, Mr. Andrews. After all, kidnapping is no child's play.
Lower the boats!
What a hell cat. No controlling these modern girls.
They're terrible!
on that?
comprenez ?
What do you want?
I don't want to eat!
And there's one more thing I don't want! Definitely! That's to see you.
Why don't you put me in chains?
All right! Put me in chains! Do anything you want! But I'm not going to eat a thing until you let me off this boat!
I won't stand for it! I won't stand for your running my life! Why do you insist on it!
Yes. I know.
You're wasting your time. I'm already married to him.
How many times have I told you not to bring any food in here.
Smart, aren't you! So subtle.
You can't tempt me.
Do you hear? I won't eat!
I hope you're not comparing yourself to Napoleon. He was a strategist. Your idea of strategy is to use a lead pipe.
Most humiliating thing ever happened to me.
Where are you taking me?
South America!
You'll have a corpse on your hands! That what You'll have. I won't eat a thing while I'm on this boat.
What do you expect to accomplish by all this? I'm already married!
You'll never do it! You can't do it!
What've you got against King Westley?
You only met him once .
He's one of the best fliers in the country. Right now he's planning a trip to Japan.
if you're a shining example.
Your whole life is devoted to just one thing. To accumulate more money. At least there's romance in what he's doing.
You've been telling me what not to do since I was old enough to remember.
I'm sick of it!
a year or so. If it's wrong, King and I will be the first to know it. We can get a divorce, can't we? Now, be a dear, and let me off the boat. Keeping me prisoner like this is so silly.
I come from a long line of stubborn idiots!
I won't thank you! I'll never thank you!
I'll shout to my heart's content! I'll scream if I want to.
Thanks.
The scene dissolves to the DECK of the YACHT as Ellie's pursuers clamber aboard, Andrews waiting for them.
Oh, thank you. Thank you very much.
Here.
Replies.Didascalie: (she takes the ticket and change from the old lady, and hands her a bill)

Replies.Reply: When does the bus leave?
Thank you.
I beg your pardon!
Driver!
Are those seats reserved?
Thank you.
Tell that man not to drive so fast.
Yes. Tell that man to drive slowly.
I don't know what you're raving about, young man. And, furthermore, I'm not interested.
Oh, my heavens! It's gone!
What happened?
What am I going to do now?
No, I've got that, all right. But my money. All I have here is four dollars. I've got to get to New York with it.
Yes . . . I guess I will.
No. I'd rather you didn't.
I don't want it reported!
See here, can you understand English! I don't want it reported!
Please stay out of my affairs! I want to be left alone.
A close-up of PETER shows him glaring after her.
Replies.Didascalie: (with which she disappears from the scene)

Replies.Reply: Silly, isn't it?
Everybody's gone.
Oh, thank you.
That was foolish of me. Why didn't you shove me away?
No, thank you.
Thank you so much.
How much time have I?
I'm going over to the Windsor Hotel.
Yes. I may be a few minutes late.
Where's the bus to New York?
Seems to me I've already thanked you for that.
What time is the next bus to New York?
Eight o'clock! Why, that's twelve hours!
What are you excited about? You missed the bus, too.
Don't tell me you did it on my account!
You needn't concern yourself about me, young man. I can take care of myself.
My ticket?
Oh, thank you. Must have fallen out of my pocket.
What are you talking about?
Will you please tell me what you're raving about!
I didn't ask for your advice.
You're not going to notify my father, are you?
If you play your cards right, you might get some money out of it.

Listen, if you'll promise not to do it, I'll pay you. I'll pay you as much as he will. You won't gain anything by giving me away as long as I'm willing to make it worth your while. I've got to get to New York without being stopped. It's terribly important to me. I'd pay now, only the only thing I had when I jumped off the yacht was my wrist watch and I had to pawn that to get these clothes. I'll give you my address and you can get in touch with me the minute you get to New York.
Seems to me you're doing excellently without any assistance.
Believe you me, you bore me to distraction.
If you promise not to snap my head off, I'd like to thank you.
Here, boy!
No. It'd be useless. Father'd get the wire before they would.
A box of chocolates, please.
You have your nerve!
That's none of your business.
Are you talking to me!
Darn clever, these Armenians.
I just had the unpleasant sensation of hearing you referred to as my husband.
for joy?
Your ego is colossal.
Compared to you, my friend, Shapeley's an amateur.
Hey, wait a minute!
Let's get something straightened out right now. If you've any peculiar ideas that I'm interested in you, forget it. You're just a headline to me.
A headline? You're not a newspaper man, are you?
Now isn't that just too cute? There's a brain behind that face of yours, isn't there? You've got everything nicely figured out, for yourself, including this.
all right.
You're not really serious about this, are you?
Smart aleck!
You haven't got a trumpet by any chance, have you?
Do you mind putting out the light?
Who are you?
Replies.Didascalie: (both sides of the blanket coming into view)

Replies.Reply: You've got a name, haven't you?
Peter Warne? I don't like it.
Pleased to meet you, Mr. Warne . . .
Replies.Didascalie: (flopping back on her pillow as she mumbles)

Replies.Reply: Goodnight, Mr. Warne.

She squirms around uncomfortably, and finding it impossible to resume her slumber, opens her eyes. The sun pouring in through the window causes her to squint. She sits up and stares outside, puzzled. Then remembering where she is she looks toward the other side of the cabin, listening for some sign of life. But there is none  ? 248 ?
What is it?
Why, it's a toothbrush! Thanks.
Why, you sweet thing, you. Where'd you get it pressed?
Why, you bully. I believe you would.
I'm out! I'm out!
Outside!
I can't go out like this.
Like this. I have no robe.
Where is the shower?
I'll find it myself.
If you don't get out of here, I'll slap that fresh mouth of yours.
Get out!
I met some very interesting women at the showers. We got to chatting about this and that. You know how time files.
I saw the little Pussinfoos girl. She's turned out quite a charming creature.
Very outspoken, too. Said I looked funny. Wasn't that cute?
Why, Peter! Don't you want to hear about our lovely friends?
Well, I hope you're not going to dictate whom I can talk to.
Thank you.
Nope. No complaints.
Why, you don't have to apologize, Mr. Warne. You'll never know how much I appreciate all this.
Must be the Spring.
He apologized for last night.
Said he didn't know we were married.
Thanks.
You think this whole business is silly, don't you? I mean running away and everything.

Yes, you do. You think I'm a fool and a spoiled brat. Perhaps I am, although I don't see how I can be. People who are spoiled are accustomed to having their own way. I never have. On the contrary, I've always been told what to do and how to do it and where and with whom. Would you believe it? This is the first time I've ever been alone with a man!
It's a wonder I'm not panic stricken.
Thanks. Nurses, governesses, chaperones, even body-guards. Oh, it's been a lot of fun.

without a body-guard. It was swell. I felt absolutely immoral. But it didn't last long. They caught up with me in a department store. I was so mad I ran out the back way and jumped into the first car I saw. Guess who was in it?
Um-hm. We rode around all afternoon. Father was frantic. By 6 o'clock he was having all the rivers dragged.
Aw, now, don't you start telling me I shouldn't dunk.
Thanks, professor.
I'd change places with a plumber's daughter any day.
That's Father at work, What'll I do?
Peter, what'll I do?
Maybe I could jump out of the window.
Do you think they'd see me?
Come here, you little fool!
What are you talking about?
Come in!
There's a man here to see you, Sweetheart.
Are you addressing me?
Don't get excited, Peter. They just asked a civil question.
Well, you don't have to lose your temper!
He didn't make a pass at me! I told you a million times!
Well, you were!
Yeah, and gotten yourself arrested!
Peter Warne, you've gone far enough. I won't stand being insulted like this another minute.
You weren't so bad yourself.
Next week "East Lynne."
story?
Oh, you are! Who made you the manager?
You always want to run everything.
I refuse to resign!
Peter!
There's something the matter with that woman. She looks ill.
I better go over and see her.
Yes.
Thank the man for me, Peter. This is the first comfortable position I've had all night.
You'd better rest. It's been a hard trip, hasn't it?
She'll be all right, soon's she gets something to eat.
some food.
Just don't tell her anything about it. You don't want her to get sick again, do you?
Come on. Let's go back to your mother.
Poor old Shapeley. You shouldn't have frightened him like that.
Yes, I noticed he was getting a little fat lately.
Ouch!
I was never built for these moonlight strolls.
Why did we have to leave the bus?
Not as long as I'm alive.
You didn't give that boy all your money?
Never! I'll get to New York if I have to starve all the way.
To New York?
I'm following you.
No.
Sorry.
Replies.Didascalie: (thereupon holding the shoes out at a safe distance)

Replies.Reply: It's the first time I've ridden "piggy-back" in years.
Of course it is.
Yes.
. . . and I've seen them ride "piggy-back."
That's silly.
And rich people have none of those qualifications, I suppose.
You're prejudiced.
My father was a great "piggy-backer."
We're not going to sleep out here, are we?
PETER'S VOICE  You can't be hungry and scared at the same time.
Well, I am.
Not if you're more hungry than scared.
I can't forget it. I'm still hungry.
I'll get my clothes all wrinkled.
What!
You're becoming terribly disagreeable lately. Snap my head off every time I open my mouth.
Replies.Didascalie: (seen close, as she is lying back on hay bed)

Replies.Reply: Peter!
Replies.Didascalie: (there is a pause while she listens, but nothing stirs, and there is more apprehension in her voice)

Replies.Reply: Peter!!
Oh, Peter! I was so scared.
I don't want it now.
Do you know?
What?
Try me.
You sound like a hobo.
Doesn't sound very exciting.
What are you thinking about?
Really?
What'd you say we're supposed to be doing?
where does the hitching come in?
If it's just the same to you, we'll sit right here till they come.
Got a toothpick?
Replies.Didascalie: (Peter comes over, sets his bag down, and prepares to wait)

Replies.Reply: She points to her front teeth, and Peter flicks the hay out of her teeth.
Needn't rub it in.
Raw?
No!!
It's a wonder you couldn't get me something I can eat.
Replies.Didascalie: (as Peter smacks his lips with satisfaction)

Replies.Reply: I hate the horrid stuff.
What if nobody stops for us?
You're an expert, I suppose.
There's no end to your accomplishments.
Oh, no!
Tch! Tch! I'm sorry for the poor things.
Clever.
You figured that all out yourself, huh?
Amazing.
Here comes a car!
I'm still watching your thumb.
When you get up to a hundred, wake me up.
Yes. But look at all the fun you had.
Mind if I try?
The scene widens as she rises and steps forward.
Mind your own business.
You might give me a little credit.
I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb.
We don't need forty cars.
Why not? I'm hungry.
Never!
Oh, Peter! What happened? Are you all right?
Replies.Didascalie: (a note of great relief in her voice)

Replies.Reply: What happened?
What'd you give him for the car?
out? Any left?
Darling!
Any luck?
Replies.Didascalie: (as she scrambles out of the car just as Peter comes up to her)

Replies.Reply: What about money?
That's swell!
I couldn't arrive in New York at three in the morning. Everybody's in bed.
Yes. You'll have a great story, won't you?
Is that the Walls of Jericho going up?
Thank you.
Am I going to see you in New York?
Why not?
No harm in your coming to see us.
Won't I ever see you again?
Peter, have you ever been in love?
Haven't you ever wanted to fall in love?
Yes. Haven't you thought about it at all? Seems to me you could make some girl wonderfully happy.
Take me with you, Peter. Take me to your island. I want to do all those things you talked about.
I love you.
I don't care. I love you. Nothing else matters. We can run away. Everything'll take care of itself.
Please, Peter. You can't go out of my life now. I couldn't live without you.
I'm sorry.
What's the matter?
Husband?
Isn't he here?
Why, he'll be back.
Can I use your telephone? I want to talk to New York.
Oh, hello, Dad.
Sorry. Must have been day-dreaming.
Stunt?
Oh, yes. I heard.
Huh?
Yes, it's beautiful.
Nothing.
Oh, no.
Sorry, Dad. I wouldn't hurt you for the world. You know that.
On the road.
No.
I don't know very much about him.
Except that I love him.
It'll do no good.
He despises me.
He despises everything I stand for. He thinks I'm spoiled and pampered, and selfish, and thoroughly insincere.
He doesn't think so much of you either.
He blames you for everything that's wrong about me. Thinks you raised me stupidly.
He's marvelous!
I don't know.
It's no use, Dad. I practically threw myself at him.
No, I'll go through with it.
It doesn't matter.
Yes, I guess I have.

I don't want to hurt anybody any more. I want to get away from all this front page publicity. It suddenly strikes me as being cheap and loathsome. I can't walk out on King now. It'll make us all look so ridiculous.
Besides, what difference does it make?
I'll never see Peter again.
Yes. Peter Warne.
Why? Do you know him?
You haven't heard from him, have you, Dad?

She has reached into his pocket and has extracted a letter, which she hurriedly opens and reads, following which we see a LETTER in Peter's handwriting. It is addressed to: "Alexander Andrews, 11 Wall Street." It reads:  "Dear Sir:  I should like to have a talk with you about a financial matter in connection with your daughter.
Looks like that was his only interest in me. The reward.
Are you going to see him?
Certainly! Pay him off. He's entitled to it. He did an excellent job. Kept me thoroughly entertained. It's worth every penny he gets.
Thanks, Mary. That's just what I need.
Well, if it isn't the groom himself! You're just in time, King.
Happy? Why shouldn't I be happy? I'm getting the handsomest man in captivity.
Here you are, King. Let's drink.
Let's drink to us .

It's up to you now. I want our life to be full of excitement, King. We'll never let up, will we? Never a dull moment. We'll get on a merry-go-round and never get off. Promise you'll never let me get off? It's the only way to live, isn't it? No time to think. We don't want to stop to think, do we? Just want to keep going.
on the lawn with a plane. It's a perfect beginning for the life we're going to lead. It sets just the right tempo.
Come on, King. You're lagging.
I hope you got your money.
Congratulations.
Why don't you stay and watch the fun? You'll enjoy it immensely.
I don't want to hear anything about him!
Anything else, Monsieur?
Very good, Monsieur.
Yessir.
We're wastin' our time. Can you picture Ellie Andrews ridin' on a bus?
Show him your credentials, Mac. I'll look around.
Take it easy, son. Take it easy.
Sorry, Mr. Warne. But you see, we're supposed to check up on everybody.
I told the old man it was the bunk.
What's up?
of the big Wall Street mug.
Here's your ticket, ma'am.
Oh, thank you. Thank you.
In about fifteen minutes.
Hey, what's going on here? I'd like to use that phone.
What?
Shh! Quiet. This is history in the making.
There's a man biting a dog in there.
Your chariot awaiteth withouteth, oh mighty King.
Is that so? That's telling him, Petey old boy.
Look out. Get back. Farewell. Farewell.
you fired the best newshound your filthy scandal sheet ever had.
That was free verse, you gashouse palooka!

That's okay by me! 'Cause as far as I'm concerned, I'm through with newspapers! See? I'm through with stupidity! I'll never write another newspaper story, for you or anybody else, if I have to starve.

Oh, so you're changing your tune, eh? Well, it's about time. But it's going to do you no good, my tough friend. It's a little too late for apologies. I wouldn't go back to work for you if you begged me on your hands and knees! I hope this is a lesson to you!
Give me any of his lip, will he? Huh! I guess he knows now what I think of his job!
Is my chariot ready?
be doing? Chasing news. You miserable worms. For what? A mere pittance! My heart goes out to you.
Good-bye.
Replies.Didascalie: (with arms extended and in tremolo voice)

Replies.Reply: Scram.
Hey, driver! How about clearing this stuff away!
If you'll be good enough to remove those newspapers I'll have a seat.
Just between you and me, I never intended taking it off.

Replies.Reply: Personally, I was raised on a bottle.
When I was a baby, I insisted on it. You know why?
Replies.Didascalie: (as the woman looks up at him, perplexed)

Replies.Reply: I never liked the idea of getting cigarette ashes in my eyes.
Huh?
He slowly lowers his arms and deposits the suitcase on the floor.
That's a long story, my friend. You see, I don't like sitting on newspapers. I did once and all the headlines came off on my white pants.
Oh, I wouldn't kid you . On the level, it actually happened. Nobody bought a paper that day. They followed me all over town and read the news from the seat of my pants.
It's okay with me. I'm not arguing.

Look here, partner. You may not like my nose. But I do. It's a good nose. The only one I've got. I always keep it out in the open where anybody can take a sock at it. If you decide to do it, make sure you don't miss.
Now, that's a brilliant answer. Why didn't I think of it? Our conversation could have been over long ago.
You win!
her buttocks.
scram.
Driver!
These seats accommodate two passengers, don't they?
Move over, lady. This is a "maybe they do."
Next time you drop in, bring your folks.
Are you talking to me?
Okay.
He got away. I suddenly found myself in the middle of the brush and not a sign of the skunk.
Maybe you'll be interested to know your bag's gone.
Yeah. I knew you'd catch on eventually.
sat in front of us, just up and took it. Boy, how that baby can run!
Don't tell me your ticket was in it?
You can wire home for some money when we get to Jacksonville.
I'll report it to the driver. About your bag, I mean.
Don't be a fool. You lost your bag. The company'll make good. What's your name?
Why, you ungrateful brat!
Yes.
I hated to wake you up.
How about some breakfast?
Good morning.
Remember me? I'm the fellow you slept on last night.
What's the matter? Wouldn't the old meanies wait for you?
Yeah. I missed it, too.
You're doing a pretty sloppy job of it.
Here's your ticket.
I found it on the seat.
You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews.
Just a spoiled brat of a rich man. You and Westley'll make an ideal team.
You'll never get away with it, Miss Andrews. Your father'll stop you before you get half way to New York.
Quit kidding! It's all over the front pages, You know, I've always been curious about the kind of a girl that would marry King Westley.
to Miami. That guy's a phony.
That's right. You didn't.
What for?
I never thought of that.

Never mind. You know I had you pegged right from the start, you're the spoiled brat of a rich father. The only way you can get anything is to buy it. Now you're in a jam and all you can think of is your money. It never fails, does it? Ever hear of the word "Humility"? No, you wouldn't. I guess it never occurred to you to just say, "Please mister, I'm in trouble. Will you help me?" No; that'd bring you down off your high horse for a minute. Let me tell you something; maybe it'd take a load off your mind. You don't have to worry about me. I'm not interested in your money or your problems. You, King Westley, your father, you're all a lot of hooey to me.
You send telegrams here?
Go on. Go on send the telegram.
Mush. Mush.
Send it collect.
Hey, you!
There's a seat over there for you.
don't mind.
Forget it. I didn't do it for you. His voice got on my nerves.
What'd you do? Wire one of your friends for money?
Never mind, son. She doesn't want it.
Beat it!
A dollar sixty! . . . You had four dollars last night! How do you expect to get to New York at the rate you're going?
You're on a budget from now on.
Shut up!
What's up?
Yeah? Where?
Yeah.
Thanks.
The view moves to the rear door of the bus. Ellie stands on the bottom step.

Replies.Reply: the night.
Hey! Come on! We're all set.
Ellie hesitates a moment, then starts toward the cabin. Now she is hurrying across the open space. En route she passes Dyke.
Come on! Come on! What are you going to do?
Yeah. Yeah, it's a gift.
Oh, I forgot to tell you. I registered as Mr. and Mrs.
I kind of half expected you to thank me.
Yeah. Yeah, not bad. How's your's?

Chalk up one for your side. Now listen, you want to get to King Westley, don't you? All right, I'm here to help you. What I want is your story, exclusive. A day-to-day account. All about your mad flight to happiness. I need that story. Just between you and me I've got to have it.

This? Oh, that's a matter of simple mathematics. These cabins cost two bucks a night and I'm very sorry to inform you, wifey dear, but the family purse won't stand for our having separate establishments.

Oh, yeah? It's all right with me. Go on out in the storm, but I'm going to follow you, see? Yeah. And if you get tough I'll just have to turn you over to your old man right now. Savvy? Now that's my whole plot in a nutshell. A simple story for simple people. Now if you behave yourself, I'll see that you get to King Westley; if not, I'll just have to spill the beans to papa. Now which of these beds do you prefer? This one? All right.
I'm very delicate in that respect. Prying eyes annoy me.
Do you mind joining the Israelites?
All right, don't join the Israelites. Perhaps you're interested in how a man undresses.
Replies.Didascalie: (seen at close range, going about the job of undressing very diffidently)

Replies.Reply: Funny thing about that. Quite a study in psychology. No two men do it alike.

Replies.Reply: A close view of ELLIE shows her standing stubbornly.
Years later his secret came out. He wore a toupee.
the pants should come next. But that's where I'm different.
Still with me, Brat?
Don't be a sucker. A night's rest'll do you a lot of good. Besides, you've got nothing to worry about. The Walls of Jericho will protect you from the big bad wolf.
Not even a mouth organ.
The big bad wolf, the big bad wolf.
Ellie smiles, and wearily she pulls her hat off her head. She sits this way a moment, thoughtfully; then, determined, she looks up.
Not at all.
Do you mind taking those things off the Walls of Jericho?
It's tough enough as it is.
What's that?
Who, me? Why, I'm the whippoorwill that cries in the night. I'm the soft morning breeze that caresses your lovely face.
Yeah. I got a name. Peter Warne.
Don't let it bother you. You're giving it back to me in the morning.
The pleasure is all mine.
I've been thinking about you.
You've had a pretty tough break at that. Twice a Missus and still unkissed.
I'll bet you're in an awful hurry to get back to New York, aren't you?
Goodnight.
ELLIE'S VOICE  What time is it?
Eight o'clock.
Come on! Hurry up! Breakfast'll be ready in no time.
If you're not out of bed by then I'm going to yank you out myself.
back of the second cottage.

He flings his robe over to her, and she disappears behind the blanket.
But make it snappy.
Your hair's cute like that. You should never comb it.
High time you got back.
Hurry up and get dressed.
been through with breakfast by this time.
I know a couple of truck drivers I'd like to have you meet sometime.
Come on, sit down.
That's your ration till lunch. Any complaints?

told you a couple of snappy stories.

No. No. It's too good a story.
Yeah?
Um. You're doing all right.
One consolation; you can never be lonesome.
Santa Claus?

Of course you shouldn't. You don't know how to do it. Dunking's an art. Don't let it soak so long. A dip and plop, into your mouth. If you let it soak so long, it'll get soft and fall off. It's all a matter of timing. I ought to write a book about it.
Just goes to show you. Twenty millions and you don't know how to dunk.
Detectives!
Don't look at me. I didn't marry King Westley.
Sit down!
Yeah. I got a letter from Aunt Betty. She says if we don't stop over at Wilkes-Barre she'll never forgive us.
want us to come.
do you want, anyway?
bustin' in here. This isn't a public park.
I got a good mind to sock you right in the nose.

You don't have to lose your temper!
Oh, so now I was drunk!
I'm sorry I didn't take another sock at him.
Aw, nuts! You're just like your old man! Once a plumber always a plumber! There isn't an ounce of brains in your whole family!
Well, I hope you find her.
Quit bawling! Quit bawling!
It'll be a dirty trick on Aunt Betty if it turns out to be a girl after all.
Say, you were pretty good. Jumping in like that. Got a brain, haven't you?
After that "The Three Musketeers."
I'd make a great D'Artagnan.

Thanks.

whole world about it!

I don't trust that chatterbox.

natural "piggy-backer."

Replies.Reply: All right. You win. Let's forget it.

Taking a married woman back to her husband. Hunh! What a prize sucker I turned out to be.

Replies.Reply: Well, take them off.
All right! Don't take them off. Do whatever you please. But shut up about it.
What's the matter?
What's got into you?
I wasn't gone more than a minute. Just went out to find you something to eat.
Here. Eat your head off.
Thought you were hungry!
But what!
Holy Jumping Catfish! You can drive a guy crazy.
Might get chilly later on.
Better use this.
You've had a lot of men crazy about you, haven't you?
I guess you've pretty much had your own way with them. That's your trouble mostly. You've always had your own way. That's why you're such a mess now.
get back to king Westley.

Nothing.

I am. I only work when I have to. Two years ago I got a notion and went to China. There was a war going on. Swell! After a while it got stale. I went down to Tahiti. Just lay on the beach for six months. What could be sweeter?
I guess not. I'd have given odds it wouldn't mean anything to you.
By a strange coincidence, I was thinking of you.
Yeah. I was just wondering what makes dames like you so dizzy.
Hitch-hiking.
A little early yet. No cars out yet.
No. But I've got a penknife.
There it is. Better swallow it. We're not going to have any breakfast.
Carrots.
Uh-huh. Want one?
You don't think I'm going around panhandling for you.
I wish you wouldn't talk too much. We let a car get away.
Oh, they'll stop, all right. It's a matter of knowing how to hail them.
Expert! Going to write a book on it. Called the "Hitch-Hikers Hail."
You think it's simple, huh?
like this.
But they're all wrong. Never get anywhere.
That shows independence. You don't care if they stop or not. 'Cause you got some money in your pocket, see?
Hm? Yeah, but it's no good if you haven't got a long face with it.
Now watch me. I'm going to use Number One. Keep your eye on that thumb, baby, and see what happens.
Something must have gone wrong. I guess I'll try number two.
I guess maybe I won't write that book after all.
You! Don't make me laugh.
What're you going to do?
What for?
Why didn't you take all your clothes off? You could have stopped forty cars.
Hey, hey, aren't you afraid you'll burn out a tonsil?
All right, let it go.
No, thanks. We're not hungry.
No.
Eat a carrot.
If you do, I'll break your neck.
Let's get out and stretch our legs.
Hey!
Come on! come on!
Just a road thief. Picks people up and runs off with their stuff. What a racket!
A black eye.

Replies.Reply: You don't have to eat the carrots.
Just passed a pond with some ducks in it.
Haven't much gas left in this thing. Got to start promoting some.
Better take the things out of the pocket of that coat. Ought to be good for ten gallons.
Yeah. He finally agreed to let us have a room.
Talked him out of it. He thinks we're going to stay a week. I'll have to think of something before morning.
I'm glad you think so. If you ask me, it's foolish. I told you there's no sense in our staying here tonight. We could make New York in less than three hours.
Okay.

Tomorrow morning, you'll be in the arms of your husband.

I probably did the world a great favor at that. Got two pinheads out of circulation.
Me?

Better go back to your bed.
Did you mean that? Would you really go?

do. When I come back in the morning, I'll buy it back from you and give you ten dollars profit? What do you say?

'er up.

to you, didn't I? Well, I got one now. Those wires I sent you were on the level. It's the biggest scoop of the year. I'm giving it to you, Joe.

a jam.

tell you that Ellen Andrews is going to have her marriage annulled.

Replies.Reply: Wait a minute, Joe. Use your bean. I couldn't afford to hand you a phoney yarn, like that. I'd be crazy. There isn't a newspaper in the country'd give me a job after that! I could go to jail!
Sure. I wouldn't blame you, either.
I am, Joe.
Yeah.
editor for just a minute.
We've been friends for a long time, haven't we? You ought to know when I'm serious. This is on the level.

I'm in love with her, Joe.
for me. Now. Minutes count. She's waiting for me in an auto camp outside of Philadelphia. I've got to get right back. You see, she doesn't know I'm gone.

'Bye, Agnes. You're beautiful. All women are beautiful!
Gordon is immediately electrified into action.

He is interrupted by the song of a meadowlark, whistling its strange melody. Peter listens to it a second time, then answers its call by imitating it. The meadowlark whistles again, and peter is highly amused.
Okay, pal. Be seein' you.
gets an idea.

See that he gets that, will you, Agnes? Tell him I was just kidding.

Yeah, wait a minute. Maybe I will come over. I'd like to get a load of that three-ring circus you're pulling. I want to see what love looks like when it's triumphant. I haven't had a good laugh in a week.
Then the LAWN of the ANDREWS ESTATE dissolves in. It is now filled with guests, who wander around, chattering gaily. The orchestra plays. A captain of waiters in the foreground instructs his men.

Collect?
Collect.

Replies.Reply: And I'm a guy that knows class when he sees it, believe you me.
You made no mistake sitting next to me.

Just between us, the kinda muggs you meet on a hop like this ain't nothing to write home to the wife about. You gotta be awful careful who you hit up with, is what I always say, and you can't be too particular, neither. Once when I was comin' through North Carolina, I got to gabbin' with a good-lookin' mama. One of those young ones, you know, and plenty classy, too. Kinda struck my fancy. You know how it is. Well, sir, you could'a knocked me over with a Mack truck. I was just warming up when she's yanked offa the bus. Who do you think she was? Huh? Might as well give up. The girl bandit! The one the papers been writin' about.
That's pretty good . . . Well, shut my big nasty mouth!

go to work. You're up against a lulu. Well, I'm here to tell you, sister, I opened up a line of fast chatter that had that dame spinnin' like a Russian dancer. Before I got through she bought enough stuff to last the firm a year. And did she put on an act when I blew town!
how she sizzles! She kinda cramped my style, though. I didn't look at a dame for three towns.
Not that I couldn't. For me it's always a cinch. I got a much better chance than the local talent.
You see, they're kinda leery about the local talent. Too close to home. Know what I mean?

I like to pick my fillies. Take you, for instance. You're my type. No kiddin' sister. I could go for you in a big way. "Fun-on-the-side Shapeley" they call me, and the accent is on the fun, believe you me.
Well, you're two up on me now.
Huh?
What's the idea?
Wife?
Oh, excuse me.
Hello, sister.
Sorry about last night. Didn't know you were married to that guy. Shoulda told me about it right off.
There I was, gettin' myself all primed for a killin', and you turn out to be an old married woman.

talking. Thereupon PETER is seen again as his lip curls up a little jealously; he returns to the cabin, following which we again see Ellie and Shapeley walking. He notices the robe she is wearing, and he looks down toward her feet, the view moving down to show Ellie's legs and feet. The pajama legs are seen protruding below the robe, the cuffs of which she has turned up. Then the view moving back up to Ellie and Shapeley, he lifts her robe playfully.
Hey, what's this? Wearing Papa's things? Now that's cute. That's what I call real lovey-dovey. Yessir.
Okay. I was just trying to make conversation.
What's up?
Peter turns, and looks at him quizzically, and the two are then seen close together.
Like to have a look at my paper?
Travelin' like this, you kinda lose track of what's goin' on in the world.
If you wanna get anywhere nowadays, you gotta keep in touch with all the news, is what I always say.
Take that story there, for instance. Be kinda sweet if we could collect that ten thousand smackers.
It's a lotta dough. If I was to run across that dame, you know what I'd do?
I'd go fifty-fifty with you .
is what I always say.
You're not making any mistake, believe you me.
Huh?
The Killer?
You're not kidnapping her, are you?
I won't say anything. Honest, I won't.
You can trust me, Mister. I'll keep my mouth shut.
Oscar Shapeley.
Orange, New Jersey.
Yeah. Just babies.
can depend on me, Mister.
No.
Gee! That musta been terrible.
I guess he had it coming to him though. But don't you worry about me. I don't talk. I never talk. Take my word for it. Gee, I wouldn't want anything to happen to my kids.
Oh, thanks, thanks, Mister. I always knew you guys were kind-hearted.
Replies.Didascalie: (grabbing Peter's hand and shaking it gratefully)

Replies.Reply: Sure. Anything you say.
Yes, ma'am?
What'sa matter, Ma? Don't you feel all right?
Ma! Ma! What'sa matter with you?
Somebody help me! Somethin's happened to her!
We ain't ate nothin' since yestidday.
Ma spent it all for the tickets. She didn't know it was gonna be so much.
I was gonna do it, but Ma wouldn't let me. She was ashamed, I guess.
I shouldn't oughta take this. Ma'll be angry.
No-o. But I shouldn't oughta take the money.
You might need it.
Thanks.
You won't be able to pass till morning.
a piece.
Up yonder. See the lights?
That's it. Dyke's Auto Camp.
Not even then, if this keeps up.
Not even then, if this keeps up.
Good evening. Hope you and your husband rest comfortably.
You can't go around bothering my tenants. I tell you, there's no girl by that name here. Besides, how do I know you're detectives?
These men are detectives, Mr. Warne.
Now look what you've done!
Your bus leaves in five minutes.
The old man's screwy!
I said, the old man's screwy!
The dame's too smart for him.
What's 'at?
Yeah!
How'd you like to be married to a wild cat like that?
Yes, sir?
We've got her wide open, sir.
I hope she's all right, sir.
Nothing, sir!
I knew she was safe.
Can't a body have some privacy around here?
Don't she look funny, Mama?
What's your name?
Replies.Didascalie: (who hasn't taken his eyes off Ellie)

Replies.Reply: Yeah. What's your name?
We're looking for somebody.
We can't do the impossible, Mr. Andrews.
I've put extra men on, all along the way.
No. He's been trailed twenty-four hours a day since this thing started. He can't even get a phone call we don't know about.
Certainly gave us a run for our money.
Yessir?
Yessir.
Yessir?
it!
You, too, McCormack.
Yeah, but I got a bag. My wife gave me one for Christmas.
I ain't got a hat.
Yeah.
They're married all right. I just seen the license.
Yeah?
Blamed if I know. I just brung 'em a trumpet.
Yeah. You know, one of those toy things. They sent me to the store to get it.
I dunno.

At this the scene cuts to the ROAD. The bus is caught in a muddy road, full of ruts, and at the moment wavers dangerously at an angle. The left front wheel is stuck in a deep hole, and the engine roars and clatters as the driver feeds the gas. Finally the bus moves forward, extricating the wheel; but just as it does, the right front wheel falls into another mud hole on the other side, and this time the bus seems hopelessly stuck, a close-up of the RIGHT WHEEL showing it revolving desperately, but in vain. The mud splashes in all directions, and the wheel seems to sink deeper and deeper. Thereupon this view cuts to the inside of the BUS. The bus  ? 263 ?
Y-e-s s-i-r!
"Hiking down the highway of love on a honeymoon.
Tonsil? Me? No! Me burn a tonsil?
. . . turn."
How about a bite to eat?
Oh, I see, young people in love are never hungry.
"Young people in love  Are very seldom hungry.
all your threats of annulment.
Well, it hasn't bothered me for a minute. Ellie and I got married because we love each other. And she's proving it; as far as I'm concerned there's going to be no annulment.
Ellie? Oh, she's no responsibility.
What would you like to have me do?
Yes, sir.
Oh, by the way, Mr Andrews, I thought of a great stunt for the reception.
Oh, no. She'll be crazy about it. Well, see you later. I'm going out on the lawn and arrange for landing space.
Goodbye.
Yes, of course.
How are you, Ellie?
You bet we did.
Whatever you say, darling.
I will.
Ellie!
What happened?
If you really mean it, I will.
Hello, Westley . . . How do you do.
The scene dissolves to the side of a lonely ROAD at night. First there is a close-up of a newspaper headline, which reads.
Will you make a statement Miss Andrews? Was it an exciting experience? How did you travel?
Magnate and Aviator Reconciled "Everything all right. Come home, darling," says Westley.
Yeah. They're all upright till they walk out on you.
Mebbe.
I don't trust him.
I told you! I told you, you couldn't trust him! He's gone!

That feller last night, that's who! He was gonna stay a week, huh? Well, he's skipped. Took the car with him, too. We wouldn't have known a thing about it until morning if I hadn't took that magnesia.
Come on, get up, don't lay there. Let's do something about it.
See that. They're gone!
Oh!!
No, he ain't! And the car's gone, too.
Yeah? What makes you think so! He took his suitcase and everything.
Kinda surprised, huh? It's just like I told you, Zeke. They ain't married a'tall . . .
Replies.Didascalie: (Ellie is perceptibly startled by this piece of news)

Replies.Reply: Serves you right. Oughta be careful who you take up with on the road. You can't go plyin' your trade in my camp.
Ain't gonna wait a minute.
Better start gettin' into your clothes.
Zeke.
Git!
You ain't gonna stick me for no phone calls. You can go down to the Sheriff's office.
And listen, next time better keep away from here. I run a respectable place.
Funny couple, ain't they?
If you ask me, I don't believe they're married.
They made me get 'em a rope and a blanket, on a night like this.
What do you reckon that's for?
A trumpet?
But what in the world do they want a trumpet for?
He looked like an upright young feller to me, Ma.
Said he was gonna stay a week.
Worst comes to the worst, we got his car for security.
Who?
Looks like it, don't it?
Here's the woman, ma.
Yeah, you'll have to git .
Not a minute!
Yeah.
Yes, Ma.
Sure. Sure, Pete.
Better not go in. He'll shoot you on sight.
Yessir.
Gordon's out back some place.
Peter Warne was just in.
Left this money. Said to tell you he was just kidding.

Yeah. She just phoned her father from an auto camp to come and get her. He's getting a police escort. Westley's going along, too. She's been traveling by bus. The moment she read that her father and Westley made up, she phoned in.

Peter pays no attention to any of this. He reaches Gordon's door, which is open. He walks directly past Agnes and enters the office. She looks up at him, puzzled. Then in GORDON'S OFFICE, Peter walks to Gordon's desk and lays the roll of bills on it. Agnes enters, watching him anxiously.
Yes, sir?
sent me for a drink.

Andrews stands a moment thoughtfully and then starts up the stairs, following which the scene dissolves to the UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR in front of Ellie's door. Andrews enters and knocks several times. Receiving no response, he gingerly opens the door.
Mr. King Westley is on his way up.
Here comes King! He's just coming down! Hurry up, everybody! Come on, Ellie!
What's happened? Where's she going?
I'm not interested.
Yes. She certainly is lucky.

Dearly beloved, we are gathered together here in the sight of God and in the face of this company to join together this man and this woman in holy matrimony. If any man can show just cause why they may not lawfully be joined together, let him speak now or else hereafter forever hold his  ? 324 ?
Ellen, wilt thou have this man to be thy wedded husband so long as ye both shall live?
